$35.5 billion in trailing 12-month free cash flow adjusted for equipment finance leases, up $48.3 billion year-over-year.

We are most pleased about the continued customer experience improvements across our businesses, driven by invention, collaboration, discipline, execution, adjusting, and reimagining from teams across Amazon.
Customers responded positively to our focus on selection, price, and convenience. We added tens of millions of new items across various categories, enhancing our broad retail selection.
We kicked off the holiday season with Prime Big Deal Days and our extended Black Friday and Cyber Monday events, which were our largest ever and helped attract new customers and Prime members.
In 2023, Amazon delivered more than 7 billion items to Prime members on the same or next day, with significant contributions from the U.S. and Europe.
We reduced our cost-to-serve globally for the first time since 2018, with the U.S. alone seeing a decrease of more than $0.45 per unit compared to the prior year.

Looking toward 2024 and beyond, we are not done lowering our cost to serve. We are focusing on inbound fulfillment architecture and inventory placement to achieve further cost reductions and speed improvements.
Advertising growth remains strong, up 26% year-over-year, driven primarily by sponsored ads and the introduction of Sponsored TV in the U.S.
AWS revenue grew 13% year-over-year in Q4, approaching an annualized run rate of $100 billion. We signed significant new deals with major companies and continue to lead in generative AI investments.

We launched Trainium2 and continued to expand Bedrock with new capabilities and models from various providers. Our application layer includes Amazon Q, an expert coding companion, and Rufus, an expert shopping assistant.
We achieved a major milestone by launching two end-to-end prototype satellites, successfully validating key systems and demonstrating our communication network capabilities.

responses.topic: Thursday Night Football and Prime Video
responses.content: Our second season of Thursday Night Football was a success, with increased viewership and ad sales. Prime Video continues to grow with exclusive content and the introduction of ads to enhance profitability.
Amazon Pharmacy has evolved, offering affordable medication options and partnering with Blue Shield of California to enhance pharmacy care for its members.

Full year 2023 CapEx was $48.4 billion, down $10.2 billion year-over-year, primarily driven by lower spend on fulfillment and transportation. In 2024, CapEx is expected to increase year-over-year, driven by infrastructure investments supporting AWS and generative AI.
We are excited about continuing our work in 2024, focusing on streamlining operations, reducing costs, and innovating to make customers' lives better and easier across all our businesses.
Worldwide revenue was $170 billion, representing a 13% year-over-year increase, excluding the impact of foreign exchange and approximately $3 billion above the top end of our guidance range.
Operating income reached $13.2 billion for the quarter, an increase of $10.5 billion year-over-year and $2.2 billion above the high end of our guidance range.

For the full year 2023, revenue was $574.8 billion, up 12% year-over-year excluding foreign exchange. Operating income tripled year-over-year to $36.9 billion. Trailing 12-month free cash flow adjusted for equipment finance leases was $35.5 billion, up $48.3 billion versus last year.
North America revenue was $105.5 billion, up 13% year-over-year, and international revenue was $40.2 billion, also up 13% year-over-year excluding foreign exchange.

responses.topic: Prime Day and Holiday Sales Events
responses.content: Prime Big Deal Days and the extended Black Friday and Cyber Monday events contributed significantly, with customers saving nearly $10 billion across millions of deals and coupons, a 70% increase year-over-year.
We delivered items at our fastest speeds ever in the U.S. and reduced our global cost-to-serve by more than $0.45 per unit in the U.S., the first reduction since 2018.
Worldwide third-party seller services revenue grew 19% year-over-year, excluding foreign exchange, with the third-party seller unit mix reaching 61%, its highest level ever.
Worldwide advertising revenue grew 26% year-over-year, driven primarily by sponsored products and improved ad relevancy through machine learning.

North America segment operating income was $6.5 billion, up $6.7 billion year-over-year, resulting in an operating margin of 6.1%, up 120 basis points quarter-over-quarter. The International segment had an operating loss of $419 million, an improvement of $1.8 billion year-over-year.

Free cash flow adjusted for finance leases was $35.5 billion for the trailing 12-month period, up $48.3 billion year-over-year. Full year 2023 CapEx was $48.4 billion, down $10.2 billion year-over-year.
For 2024, we anticipate CapEx to increase year-over-year, primarily driven by infrastructure investments supporting AWS and generative AI initiatives.
